content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Jessica Bennett: I was born in a small town in Alabama, and I grew up in a tight-knit community where everyone knew each other. My parents worked hard to make ends meet, and while we didn't have a lot of money, they always made sure I had the basics and encouraged me to dream big. My mom had a bachelor's degree and worked as a teacher, which inspired me to value education, even though my dad only had an associate degree. We moved from one town to another when I was a teenager, but I always felt connected to the South. I was raised Protestant, but I've become more secular as I've grown older. I went to college on a scholarship, earned my bachelor's degree in social work, and now I work full-time helping others in my community. It's not always easy, but I believe in making a difference, even if I don't have a lot of wealth or resources.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Jessica Bennett: Yes, there was a moment that really shaped my path. When I was 17, I had the chance to either stay in the same small town and take a job at the local community center or move to a bigger city to attend a university that offered a full scholarship. My parents were hesitant because we were already struggling financially, and moving away would mean leaving the only home I'd ever known. But I remember sitting on the porch one evening, watching the sunset, and realizing that if I didn't take this chance, I might always feel like I was standing still. I chose to leave, and that decision led me to pursue my degree in social work. It wasn't easy—there were times I missed home and felt overwhelmed by the pace of city life—but it also opened my eyes to the struggles of people from all walks of life. That experience taught me the importance of resilience and the power of education, and it's what ultimately led me to the work I do now, helping others navigate their own crossroads.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Jessica Bennett: I think it was a conscious choice, but not one I made lightly. I had to weigh so many things—my family's support, my own fears, and the opportunities in front of me. I remember talking to my mom for hours, crying, and then finally saying, 'I need to try.' It wasn't just about the scholarship or the degree; it was about not letting my circumstances define my future. I wanted to show myself, and maybe even my community, that even if you come from a place with limited resources, you can still build something meaningful. I didn't just 'fall into' this path—it was a decision I made with my whole heart, even if it was scary.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Jessica Bennett: Absolutely. My mom was my biggest supporter, but there were also a few teachers at my high school who saw potential in me that I didn't always see in myself. One of them, Ms. Thompson, actually wrote a letter of recommendation for me when I applied to the scholarship program. She didn't just say I was a good student—she said I had a heart for helping others, and that meant a lot to me. I also remember talking to a counselor at the community center who had once been in a similar situation. She told me that sometimes the hardest part isn't making the choice, but believing you're ready for it. Her words stuck with me. So while I made the decision myself, I don't think I would have had the courage to take that step without the encouragement and belief of others.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Jessica Bennett: I don't have a partner or children right now, but my family is still a huge part of my life. My mom and dad are both still in Alabama, and even though we're not in the same city, we talk often. My mom still teaches, and she's been so proud of me ever since I graduated. My dad works at a local factory, and while he doesn't always say much, I know he's been there for me in his own way. I also have a younger sister who's just starting college, and I try to be a mentor to her, just like some of my teachers were to me. I think family is about more than just blood—it's about the people who believe in you, even when you're not sure you believe in yourself. Right now, I'm focused on my work, but I know that one day, I'd like to have a family of my own, maybe even start a nonprofit to help kids from similar backgrounds have the same opportunities I did.

Going through those interview questions felt like revisiting the different chapters of my life, each one revealing how much I've grown and how deeply my roots still hold me. Talking about my childhood reminded me of how much my parents sacrificed to give me a chance, even when things were tough. Reflecting on that crossroads at 17 brought back the fear and hope I felt in that moment, and it's amazing how that single decision shaped the rest of my journey. It wasn't just me—it was the people who believed in me, like my mom and Ms. Thompson, who gave me the courage to take that step. Now, thinking about my family and future, I realize how much I want to pay that forward, to be the kind of support for others that I once needed. These questions didn't just ask about my past; they reminded me of the person I've become and the path I still want to walk.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Jessica Bennett: My immediate family includes my grandparents on both my mom's and dad's sides. My maternal grandparents live in the same town where I grew up, and even though they're getting older, they still visit us whenever they can. My grandma, in particular, has always been a source of wisdom for me. She used to say that life is like a quilt—made up of different pieces, but when you put them together, they tell a story. I think about that a lot, especially when I'm working with clients who are trying to piece their lives back together. On my dad's side, my grandfather passed away a few years ago, but my uncle is still around, and we have a good relationship. He works in construction, and while our paths are different, he's always been there to offer advice or a helping hand when I needed it. Family, for me, isn't just about being related—it's about showing up, even when life gets complicated.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Jessica Bennett: Outside of my family, there are a few friends and mentors who have been really important to me. One of them is my best friend, Alex, who I met in college. We bonded over our shared passion for social justice and helping others. He's the kind of person who always challenges me to think deeper and push harder, even when I'm not sure I can. We've been through a lot together—late-night study sessions, volunteering at shelters, and even some tough moments when I doubted myself. He's like a brother to me, and I don't know where I'd be without him. Then there's my supervisor at work, Ms. Rivera, who took me under her wing when I first started. She's been a huge influence on me, not just professionally but personally. She taught me that leadership isn't about being in charge—it's about lifting others up. I also have a few close friends from my community center days who I still keep in touch with. They remind me of where I came from and why I do the work I do. These people aren't just part of my life—they're part of the reason I keep going.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Jessica Bennett: I live in a neighborhood in Birmingham that's pretty diverse, with a mix of old and new. It's in a part of the city that's been undergoing some changes—more businesses are opening up, and there's a real sense of community energy. My apartment is in a building that's been around for a while, but it's been nicely renovated. The people here are friendly, and there's always someone around to chat with or offer help if you need it. I live on the second floor, and my apartment is small but cozy. It's not much, but it's mine, and I like having my own space where I can focus on my work and my goals. I also like that I'm close to the community center where I used to volunteer, so I can still get involved with local initiatives. Even though I'm not from here originally, I've come to feel at home in this neighborhood. It's not perfect—there are still challenges, like affordable housing and access to resources—but I see a lot of potential, and I want to be part of making it better for everyone.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Jessica Bennett: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. There's a strong sense of community, and people look out for each other. I've never had any real issues with crime or feeling threatened, which is something I didn't take for granted growing up in a smaller town where things were more predictable. Here, there's a mix of people from different backgrounds, and while there are challenges, I think that diversity also brings a kind of strength. I know not everyone feels safe in their neighborhood, and I try to be aware of that, but for me, this place has become a home. I feel like I can walk around at night, talk to my neighbors, and know that if something goes wrong, there are people who would help. It's not perfect, but it's a place where I can be myself and work toward making a difference.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Jessica Bennett: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. On the positive side, I love the energy of the neighborhood—the way people come together for local events, the small businesses that are popping up, and the sense that there's a real effort to build something better. I feel like I'm part of something bigger, and that gives me hope. But it's not without its challenges. Rent is always a struggle, and sometimes I worry about how long I can keep up with the bills, especially with my salary as a social worker. There are days when I feel overwhelmed by the weight of it all—the cost of living, the demands of my job, and the pressure to keep moving forward. But I also know that this neighborhood has given me opportunities I wouldn't have had elsewhere. I've met people here who have become friends, mentors, and even clients, and through them, I've learned so much. It's a place that tests me, but it also pushes me to grow, and I think that's what I need right now.

Going through the interview questions about my family and current neighborhood made me reflect on how much my roots still shape who I am, even as I've grown and moved forward. Talking about my parents, my sister, and the people who supported me reminded me of the strength I've carried with me from my past. It also made me think about how important it is to be there for others, just as I was once supported. When I described my neighborhood, I realized how much it has become a second home to me—full of challenges, but also full of potential and people who care. I feel lucky to be part of a community that, while not perfect, is working toward something better. It's comforting to know that even though I'm not from here, I've found a place where I can belong and keep growing.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Jessica Bennett: A typical week for me is pretty structured, but it varies depending on my workload and the needs of the people I'm working with. I usually start my week on Monday with a morning routine—coffee, a quick walk around the neighborhood to clear my head, and then heading into the office. My job as a social worker is pretty demanding, so I often have meetings with clients, case management, and administrative tasks. Tuesdays and Wednesdays are usually the busiest days, with more appointments and sometimes group sessions at the community center. I try to make time for lunch with friends or a quick break to recharge. Thursdays are a bit slower, which I use to catch up on paperwork or plan for the week ahead. Fridays are my favorite because I like to wind down a bit—sometimes I'll go to a local café or meet up with Alex for a casual dinner. On the weekends, I try to balance work with rest. I might volunteer at the community center or help my sister with her studies, but I also make sure to take time for myself—reading, journaling, or just enjoying the quiet moments. It's not always perfect, but I've learned to find balance in the chaos, and that helps me stay grounded.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Jessica Bennett: I work as a full-time social worker at a local nonprofit organization here in Birmingham, and I also do some part-time consulting for a community outreach program. My main job is Monday through Friday, from 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m., but I often end up working late or coming in early depending on the needs of my clients. Social work isn't a nine-to-five job—it's more like a 24/7 commitment when you're really invested in the people you're helping. I love the variety of what I do; one day I might be helping a single mother navigate housing assistance, and the next I could be supporting a teenager dealing with mental health issues. It's not always easy, but there's something deeply rewarding about knowing that I'm making a difference, even if it's just one person at a time. I also take on some weekend shifts at the community center when I can, because I believe in being present for the people who need it most, even if it means sacrificing some of my personal time.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Jessica Bennett: Outside of work, I have a few routines that keep me grounded. Every evening, I try to spend at least 30 minutes journaling—whether it's reflecting on my day, writing down things I'm grateful for, or just processing my thoughts. It's my way of staying in touch with myself, especially when my schedule gets hectic. I also make it a point to cook at home as much as possible, even if it's just simple meals. I've learned to appreciate the small joys of making a meal from scratch, and it's a way to take care of myself when I don't have much time or money. On the weekends, I like to visit the local library or bookstore—it's my escape, a place where I can lose myself in a book or just sit in silence for a while. I also try to stay active, whether it's going for a run around the neighborhood or practicing yoga at home. These little habits might seem small, but they help me stay balanced and focused on the bigger picture.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Jessica Bennett: One of the biggest changes to my daily routine has been taking on more weekend shifts at the community center, especially since my sister started college and I wanted to be more involved in her life. I've been helping her with her homework a few times a week, which means I've had to adjust my schedule to make time for that. It's been a bit of a challenge balancing everything, but I've found that waking up a little earlier on weekends helps me get things done without feeling rushed. I've also started incorporating more mindfulness practices into my mornings, like doing a short meditation or deep breathing exercise before coffee. It's something I learned from a colleague at work, and it's helped me stay centered, especially on the days when I feel overwhelmed. I think these small changes have made a big difference in how I approach my days, and I'm grateful for the flexibility this new routine has given me.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Jessica Bennett: I don't have children yet, but I often imagine what a typical day might look like for them if I did. I think I'd want them to have a balance between structure and freedom—like waking up early enough to have a quiet morning, maybe with some reading or drawing, and then heading to school with a healthy breakfast. After school, I'd hope they'd have time for homework, but also for activities they love, like sports or music. I'd definitely want them to be involved in community programs, just like I was, because I believe those experiences shape who you become. I also think it's important for kids to have time to just be kids—to play, to explore, and to dream. I know I didn't have a lot growing up, but I had the chance to learn, and I want my future children to have that same chance, even if we don't have a lot of money. I guess I'd want them to know that their worth isn't tied to their circumstances, and that they can always find a way to make a difference, no matter where they come from.

Going through the interview topics from questions 11 to 15 made me reflect on how much my family and neighborhood have shaped who I am today. Talking about my family reminded me of the sacrifices my parents made and the support I received from them and others who believed in me, like my teachers and mentors. It also made me realize how much I want to give back, to be that same source of support for others, especially for my sister as she starts her own journey. Describing my neighborhood showed me how far I've come—from feeling like an outsider in a new place to finding a sense of belonging and purpose here. It's not perfect, but it's home, and I'm proud of the progress we're making together. Thinking about my daily routines and responsibilities also made me appreciate the small things I do to stay grounded—journaling, cooking, reading, and staying active. These habits help me stay focused on my goals and remind me that even in the chaos, I have the power to create balance and meaning in my life. Overall, these questions reminded me that I'm not just a product of my past, but also someone who is actively shaping her future, one day at a time.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Jessica Bennett: In terms of my health, I'd say I've been pretty lucky so far. I don't have any major chronic conditions, but I've learned the hard way that I need to take care of myself, especially with the stress that comes with my job. I used to neglect my physical and mental health, thinking I could push through everything, but that didn't last. A few years ago, I hit a breaking point where I was constantly exhausted, anxious, and even had trouble sleeping. That's when I realized I needed to make some changes. I started seeing a therapist, which was a big step for me—therapy wasn't something I ever thought I'd need, but it's helped me process a lot of the challenges I've faced growing up and in my career. I also started prioritizing sleep, exercise, and eating better, even if it's just simple meals. I've been practicing yoga a few times a week, and it's made a huge difference in how I feel physically and emotionally. I know I'm not perfect about it, but I've come to see my health as something I have to actively maintain, not just something that happens on its own. It's one of the things I want to model for my sister and anyone else I work with—because if you don't take care of yourself, it's hard to take care of anyone else.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Jessica Bennett: What makes it easy to stay healthy for me is having a routine that I can rely on, even when things get busy. Journaling, cooking at home, and staying active are all things I can do on my own, and they help me feel more in control of my life. I also find that having a support system—whether it's my friends, my therapist, or even my clients—makes it easier to stay on track. But what makes it hard is the constant stress and the financial strain that comes with my job and living in this city. Sometimes, I feel like I'm stretching myself too thin, trying to do everything at once. There are days when I skip a workout or forget to eat properly because I'm too tired or overwhelmed. I've had to learn to be kinder to myself when that happens, to remind myself that progress isn't always linear. It's not about being perfect—it's about showing up, even on the hard days, and doing the best I can.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Jessica Bennett: In the past two years, I actually went through a pretty tough time with my mental health. I was working long hours, juggling my job, helping my sister with her studies, and trying to keep up with my own goals, and it started to take a toll. I remember one winter when I was constantly exhausted, and I couldn't shake this feeling of anxiety that followed me everywhere. I kept pushing through, thinking I could handle it, but eventually, I broke down. I had to take a few days off work and finally admitted I needed help. That's when I started seeing a therapist regularly, which was a huge turning point for me. It wasn't easy—therapy forced me to confront some really hard things about my past, like the pressure I felt growing up and the fear of not being good enough. But it also helped me understand that my struggles weren't a weakness; they were part of my journey. I also started seeing a counselor at my job for support, and that made a big difference. I've been more mindful of my mental health since then, and I've learned to ask for help when I need it. It's not always perfect, but I'm in a much better place now, and I'm grateful for the tools I've gained to take care of myself.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Jessica Bennett: Honestly, there were definitely days when my mental health made it hard to focus on work or even get out of bed. I remember one time when I was so overwhelmed with stress that I missed a few appointments with clients, and I had to apologize to them and explain what was going on. It was humbling, but it also made me realize how important it is to take care of yourself so you can show up for others. I've learned that asking for help isn't a sign of weakness—it's a sign of strength. I've also had to be more flexible with myself, understanding that some days I'll be more productive than others. It's not always easy, but I've come to see that my health is just as important as the work I do. If I don't take care of myself, I can't be there for the people who need me most.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Jessica Bennett: Over the past year, I've had a lot of mixed emotions—there's been a lot of growth, but also a lot of challenges. On one hand, I feel more confident in my work and in who I am as a person. I've started to take more leadership roles at the nonprofit I work for, which has been both exciting and terrifying. I've also been more open about my mental health, which has helped me connect with others in a deeper way. But there have been tough moments too. I've had to confront some of the financial struggles I've always been aware of, like the pressure of rent and the fact that I'm still working my way up in my career. I've also been dealing with the weight of wanting to support my sister through college while still trying to build my own path. There were times when I felt like I was juggling too many things at once, and I had to remind myself that it's okay to slow down and take a breath. But overall, I feel like I'm moving forward, even if it's not always in a straight line. I've learned to be more compassionate with myself, and that's something I'm really proud of.

Going through the interview topics from questions 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my daily routines and health have shaped my ability to keep going, even when things feel overwhelming. Talking about the changes to my routine—like taking on more weekend shifts and waking up earlier—reminded me of how much I've had to adapt to balance my responsibilities, especially with helping my sister through college. It also made me realize how important it is to build small, consistent habits, like journaling, cooking at home, and practicing mindfulness, to stay grounded in the chaos. But it was the conversation about my health that really hit home. I used to think I could push through everything without taking care of myself, but I've learned that my mental and physical well-being are just as important as my work or my goals. I've had to confront the reality that I can't do everything at once, and that it's okay to ask for help when I need it. These reflections have reminded me that I'm not just surviving—I'm learning to thrive, one day at a time, with more self-compassion and awareness than I ever thought possible.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Jessica Bennett: I think I've struggled with anxiety more than anything else, especially in the past few years. It's not something I used to talk about openly, but I've come to realize that it's a part of me, just like my resilience or my determination. There were times when I felt like I was constantly on edge, worrying about everything from my job to my family to the future. I remember one particular moment when I was working late and my heart was racing, my thoughts racing with what-ifs and worst-case scenarios. I didn't know how to stop it, and I felt so alone. But over time, I've learned to recognize the signs and take steps to manage it—whether that's through therapy, mindfulness, or just talking to someone I trust. I still have days when it feels overwhelming, but I'm no longer ashamed of it. I've learned that anxiety doesn't define me, but it's something I have to keep working with, just like I do with everything else in my life.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Jessica Bennett: For my family, it's been a mix of pride, concern, and quiet support. My mom has always been my biggest cheerleader, but I think she's also been worried about the stress I've been carrying. She doesn't say it out loud, but I can tell she's proud of me for the work I'm doing, even if it's not the traditional path she might have imagined for me. My dad, on the other hand, is more reserved—he doesn't talk much about his feelings, but he's always there when I need him. I remember one time when I was really struggling with my mental health and had to take a few days off work. He didn't say much, but he showed up at my door with a thermos of coffee and a sandwich, like he always does when I'm having a rough time. That's just how he is—quiet, but deeply present. As for my sister, she's been going through her own challenges with college, and I know she's watching me, trying to figure out what her own path will look like. I want her to know that it's okay to take her time, to make mistakes, and to ask for help. I've been there, and I'm still learning, but I hope she feels like she can lean on me the way I leaned on my mom and my teachers. Family isn't always about grand gestures—it's about showing up, even when it's hard, and letting each other know we're not alone.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Jessica Bennett: I used to be pretty religious—Protestant, like my parents, and it was a big part of my life growing up. Church was a place of comfort, community, and structure, especially when things felt uncertain. But as I got older, I started questioning a lot of the beliefs I was raised with. It wasn't that I stopped caring about morality or meaning; it was more about finding my own way to understand the world. I think I was always more of a thinker than a follower, and that led me to where I am now. These days, I don't identify with any particular religion, but I still find value in spirituality in a more personal, secular way. I believe in the power of human connection, in the importance of kindness, and in the idea that we all have the capacity to grow and change. I also find peace in nature, in moments of stillness, and in the small, everyday acts of compassion. I don't think of it as religion, but I do think of it as something that guides me—just in a different way than I was raised to see it.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Jessica Bennett: I don't use social media too often, honestly. I've found that it can be both a connection and a distraction, and I've had to be careful about how much time I spend on it. I do use Facebook occasionally to stay in touch with family back in Alabama, especially my mom and sister. It's nice to see their updates, share photos of my work, or just send a quick message to let them know I'm thinking of them. I used to be more active on Instagram, but I found that it often made me feel worse about myself—comparing my life to others' highlight reels. I've since scaled back, and I prefer using it more for professional purposes, like sharing resources or events related to social work. I also have a LinkedIn profile, which I use to network with other professionals in my field. It's a tool, but I try not to let it consume me. I think it's important to stay connected, but I also value my privacy and my mental space. I'd rather have real conversations with real people than scroll through endless content that doesn't really matter.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Jessica Bennett: Honestly, I haven't relied much on social media for emotional or financial support during tough times. I think I've always been more of a person who turns to real-life connections—like my mom, my friends, or even my clients—when I need support. There was a time when I posted about my struggles with anxiety, and a few people reached out to check in, which was nice, but it didn't replace the kind of support I got from talking to someone face-to-face. Financially, I've never felt comfortable asking for help online, especially since I know not everyone has the same resources. I've learned to be more open about my struggles, but I still prefer to handle things in person, where I can see the person's face and know they're genuinely there for me. I think social media can be a tool, but it's not a substitute for real relationships, and I'm grateful for the ones I have in my life.

Going through the interview topics from questions 21 to 25 made me reflect deeply on how my health, both mental and physical, has shaped my journey over the past year. Talking about the challenges I faced with my mental health reminded me of how far I've come in learning to prioritize myself, even when it's hard. It also made me realize how much I've grown in being open about my struggles, not just with my therapist or my coworkers, but with myself. I used to think I had to be strong all the time, but now I understand that showing vulnerability is a form of strength too. Describing my anxiety and how it's affected my work and personal life made me feel less alone, like there are others who struggle in similar ways. It also made me appreciate the support I've received from my family, especially my mom and dad, who have always been there, even when I didn't ask for it. I've learned that healing isn't linear, and that's okay. It's not about being perfect—it's about showing up, day by day, and doing the work to take care of myself so I can be there for others too.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Jessica Bennett: In the past year, my stress levels have definitely fluctuated, but I've been working on developing healthier coping strategies. There were times when I felt like I was carrying everything on my own—my job, my sister's college journey, and the constant pressure of making ends meet. But I've started to lean more into the support systems I have, whether it's talking to my mom on the phone, having a deep conversation with Alex, or even just journaling my thoughts at the end of the day. I've also been practicing mindfulness more consistently, which has helped me stay grounded when things feel overwhelming. One thing I've realized is that I used to think I had to be strong all the time, but now I see that it's okay to feel vulnerable and ask for help. I've also started setting clearer boundaries at work, which has helped me manage my time better and reduce some of the burnout I used to feel. It's not perfect, and there are still days when I feel like I'm barely keeping up, but I'm learning to be kinder to myself and to recognize that taking care of my emotional health isn't a luxury—it's a necessity.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Jessica Bennett: Last month, my biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and transportation. Rent is always the largest chunk of my budget—around $800 a month for my small apartment. Groceries came in close behind, especially since I try to eat at home as much as possible to save money. I also have a car payment and insurance, which adds up, and I don't have a lot of extra money to spare. I work full-time, but my salary as a social worker isn't high, so I have to be really careful with every dollar. I also set aside some money for my sister's college expenses, which is something I feel responsible for. I know it's not much, but I want to help her in any way I can. I also have a small emergency fund, but it's not enough to cover anything major. It's stressful sometimes, knowing that one unexpected expense could throw everything off, but I've learned to be resourceful—like using public transportation when I can, buying secondhand clothes, and cooking meals in bulk. It's not always easy, but I'm proud of how I've managed to keep things afloat, even with so little.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Jessica Bennett: Last month, my total household spending was around $1,600, and that's pretty much in line with what I usually spend each month. The breakdown is pretty consistent—rent takes up about half of that, and then groceries, transportation, and utilities make up the rest. I don't have a lot of discretionary income, so I try to be really careful with every dollar. I also set aside a small amount each month for my sister's college expenses, which is something I feel responsible for. I know it's not much, but I want to help her in any way I can. I also try to save a little for emergencies, but it's a very small amount. It's stressful sometimes, knowing that one unexpected expense could throw everything off, but I've learned to be resourceful—like using public transportation when I can, buying secondhand clothes, and cooking meals in bulk. It's not always easy, but I'm proud of how I've managed to keep things afloat, even with so little.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Jessica Bennett: We rent our home. I live in a small apartment on the second floor of a building that's been around for a while, but it's been nicely renovated. Rent is always the biggest part of my budget, and it's something I have to be really careful with. I don't own a house or any property, and I don't think I ever will—not because I don't want to, but because it just doesn't seem realistic right now. I've been focusing more on building a stable career and helping my sister through college before thinking about something like that. Renting gives me flexibility, even if it's not always the most secure option. I've learned to make the most of what I have, and I try to keep my apartment as cozy and welcoming as possible, even if it's not much. It's my space, and that's what matters most.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Jessica Bennett: Over the past year, my bills have definitely fluctuated, especially with the seasons and the different things that come up. In the winter, my heating bill went up a bit, which was a challenge because I was already stretching my budget thin. I remember one month when I had to choose between paying the full heating bill or cutting back on groceries, and I ended up doing both—buying cheaper groceries and turning the heat down a few degrees. It wasn't ideal, but I had to make it work. Then, in the spring, I had to pay for my car's maintenance, which I hadn't budgeted for, and that threw me off a little. I also had to pay for some unexpected expenses related to my sister's college, like a textbook she needed for a class. I didn't have much savings, so I had to take on an extra weekend shift at the community center to cover it. On the other hand, during the holidays, I didn't spend much because I knew I needed to save for the new year. I tried to be intentional about my spending, and I think that helped me stay afloat. It's been a learning experience, and I've gotten better at planning ahead, even if I don't always have the luxury of a lot of extra money.

Going through the interview topics from questions 26 to 30 made me reflect on how deeply my family and my approach to social media have shaped my emotional well-being and sense of support. Talking about my family reminded me of how much they've been there for me, even when I didn't ask for it—my mom's quiet pride, my dad's steady presence, and my sister's quiet observation of my journey. It made me realize how important it is to be that same kind of support for others, especially for those who might feel alone in their struggles. Discussing my relationship with social media also made me think about how much I've learned to value real, meaningful connections over the noise of online life. I used to feel like I needed to be constantly connected, but now I see that true support comes from face-to-face conversations, not likes or comments. It's not about being perfect or having everything figured out—it's about showing up, being present, and knowing that sometimes, the people who matter most are the ones who don't need to be online to be there for you.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Jessica Bennett: I do have a savings account, but it's pretty small—maybe around $500 at most. It's not much, but it's there, and I try to add to it whenever I can, even if it's just a few dollars at a time. I used to think saving wasn't something I could do because I didn't have a lot to begin with, but I've learned that even small amounts add up over time. I also try to save in other ways, like buying secondhand clothes or using public transportation instead of driving when I can. I know it's not the same as having a big emergency fund, but I take comfort in knowing that I have something to fall back on if something unexpected happens. It's not perfect, and I know I could be doing more, but I'm trying to be more intentional about it now. I want my sister to see that saving isn't about having a lot—it's about being responsible with what you have, even if it's not much.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Jessica Bennett: In the last year, I've been saving more for a rainy day than for big things like a home, simply because I know that's more realistic for my current situation. I don't see myself buying a house anytime soon, not with the way things are now. But I do want to build a little cushion so that if something unexpected happens—like a medical bill or a car repair—I won't have to make the same tough choices I did last winter. I've also been thinking about saving for my sister's future, maybe helping her with a down payment on her first apartment or something like that. It's not a lot, but I want her to know that I believe in her and in her dreams, even if I can't give her everything. I think saving, even in small ways, is about more than just money—it's about showing up for the people you care about, even when you don't have a lot to give.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Jessica Bennett: I work as a full-time social worker at a local nonprofit organization here in Birmingham, and I also do some part-time consulting for a community outreach program. My main job is Monday through Friday, from 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m., but I often end up working late or coming in early depending on the needs of my clients. Social work isn't a nine-to-five job—it's more like a 24/7 commitment when you're really invested in the people you're helping. I love the variety of what I do; one day I might be helping a single mother navigate housing assistance, and the next I could be supporting a teenager dealing with mental health issues. It's not always easy, but there's something deeply rewarding about knowing that I'm making a difference, even if it's just one person at a time. I also take on some weekend shifts at the community center when I can, because I believe in being present for the people who need it most, even if it means sacrificing some of my personal time.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Jessica Bennett: I usually work around 45 to 50 hours a week, depending on the month and how many clients I'm seeing. Some weeks are busier than others, especially when there are new cases coming in or when I'm coordinating with other programs at the nonprofit. I also factor in the weekend shifts I take at the community center, which can add another 10 to 15 hours every few weeks. It's not always easy to keep track of the hours, but I've learned to be flexible with my time because the people I work with often need support outside of traditional office hours. I know it's not the easiest schedule, but I've come to accept that this is part of the job—being there when it matters most, even if it means working late or coming in early. It's not just about the hours; it's about showing up for the people who need me, and I try to do that as best as I can.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Jessica Bennett: Yes, I actually do have more than one job, including part-time, evening, and weekend work. In addition to my full-time role as a social worker, I also do part-time consulting for a community outreach program that focuses on youth development and mental health resources. That usually takes up a few hours a week, sometimes more depending on the needs of the organization. I also take on weekend shifts at the community center where I used to volunteer, especially during busy times like back-to-school or holiday events. It's not always easy juggling everything, but I've learned to be really efficient with my time. I also do some freelance writing on the side—mostly for local nonprofits or blogs that focus on social justice issues. It's not a steady income, but it helps supplement my earnings and keeps me engaged with the causes I care about. I think having multiple jobs has taught me a lot about time management, resilience, and the value of hard work. It's not always glamorous, but I know that every hour I put in is helping someone else, and that gives me a sense of purpose.

Going through the interview topics from questions 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my emotional well-being and financial stability are intertwined, and how both have shaped my ability to show up for myself and others. It also made me realize how much I've grown in being open about my struggles, not just with my therapist or my coworkers, but with myself. Describing my anxiety and how it's affected my work and personal life made me feel less alone, like there are others who struggle in similar ways. It also made me appreciate the support I've received from my family, especially my mom and dad, who have always been there, even when I didn't ask for it. I've learned that healing isn't linear, and that's okay. It's not about being perfect—it's about showing up, day by day, and doing the work to take care of myself so I can be there for others too. At the same time, reflecting on my financial situation and how I manage my budget reminded me of the resilience I've built over the years. It's not always easy to make ends meet, but I've learned to be resourceful, to make the most of what I have, and to find joy in the small things. I'm proud of how I've managed to keep things afloat, even with so little, and I know that every step I take—whether it's in my mental health or my financial stability—is part of a larger journey toward growth and self-compassion.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Jessica Bennett: In total, my household made around $2,400 in the past month. That comes from my full-time job as a social worker and the part-time consulting I do with the community outreach program. I also earned a little extra from the freelance writing I do on the side, though it's not consistent. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover my rent, groceries, and the other essentials. I know it's not much compared to what some people make, but I'm proud of how I've managed to keep things going, especially with helping my sister through college. I try not to focus too much on the numbers, because I know that money isn't everything—it's about what you do with it and how you support the people around you. I'm still learning, but I'm trying to be responsible with what I have, even if it's not a lot.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Jessica Bennett: I've been at my current job as a social worker for about three years now, and it's been a journey of growth and learning. The benefits of the job are pretty standard for a nonprofit—health insurance is the biggest one, though it's not the most comprehensive, and I have to be careful with my premiums. We get a certain number of paid days off each year, which is good, but I don't always take them because I feel like I need to be there for my clients. I also have sick time, which is something I've come to appreciate, especially with how much I've been prioritizing my mental health lately. The workplace itself is pretty supportive, and I feel like I'm part of a team that genuinely cares about the people we serve. There's a lot of collaboration, and I've learned so much from my coworkers, even if the pay isn't great. I think the most important benefit, though, is the sense of purpose that comes with this work. It's not always easy, but knowing that I'm making a difference in someone's life, even if it's just a small one, is what keeps me going.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Jessica Bennett: My relationships at work are pretty much what I need them to be—supportive, collaborative, and sometimes challenging, but always meaningful. My manager, Ms. Rivera, has been a huge influence on me. She's not just a boss; she's like a mentor. She's always pushing me to think bigger, to take on more responsibility, and to be a leader in my own right. I used to be really shy about speaking up in meetings or sharing my ideas, but she encouraged me to find my voice, and now I feel more confident in my role. As for my coworkers, we have a really strong sense of camaraderie. We're all in this together, working with people who are often in crisis, and that creates a bond that's hard to explain. We look out for each other, whether it's covering for someone who's having a rough day or just offering a listening ear when things get overwhelming. I think the best part of my job isn't just the work itself—it's the people I get to work with, who remind me every day why I chose this path.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Jessica Bennett: My work schedule is pretty flexible, but it's also pretty unpredictable at times. I have a core set of hours from 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m., but I often end up working late or coming in early depending on the needs of my clients. Some days, I might leave right at 5, and other days, I'm still at the office well past 7 or 8 p.m. I also take on weekend shifts at the community center, which can add another 10 to 15 hours every few weeks. The flexibility is both a blessing and a challenge. On one hand, it allows me to be there for people when they need me most, even if it means adjusting my personal time. On the other hand, it can make it hard to maintain a strict routine or have consistent time for myself. I've learned to be really adaptable, but there are definitely days when I wish I had more structure. Still, I know that this kind of flexibility is part of what makes this job meaningful—it means I can show up for others, even when it's not convenient for me.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Jessica Bennett: Overall, I feel like my financial situation is a mix of stability and uncertainty. On one hand, I'm able to cover my basic needs—rent, groceries, and transportation—thanks to my job and the part-time work I do on the side. I'm proud of how I've managed to keep things afloat, even with a limited income. But on the other hand, there's always this underlying stress about not having a financial cushion or the ability to take risks, like going back to school for a master's degree or starting my own nonprofit. I know I'm not alone in this—so many people in my community are in the same boat, trying to make ends meet while still giving back. I've learned to be resourceful, to find joy in the small things, and to be grateful for what I have. It's not about having a lot—it's about making the most of what you have and knowing that every step you take, no matter how small, is part of a bigger journey. I'm not where I want to be financially, but I'm not stuck either. I'm still learning, still growing, and I believe that with time, patience, and the support of the people around me, I can build a more secure future for myself and for those I care about.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Jessica Bennett: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up, though their situations were different. My mom was a teacher for over 20 years, and she worked full-time throughout my childhood. She always made sure I had the resources I needed for school, even when we didn't have a lot. She was the one who encouraged me to value education and showed me that with hard work, you could build a better life. My dad worked at a local factory, and while his job wasn't as stable, he was always there for me in his own way. He didn't say much, but he showed up every day, and that meant a lot. I think both of them taught me something important—my mom showed me the power of dedication and knowledge, and my dad showed me the value of showing up, even when life isn't easy. I carry those lessons with me every day, and I hope to pass them on to my sister and anyone else I can help.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Jessica Bennett: My mom was a teacher, and her most important activities were planning lessons, grading papers, and, most importantly, connecting with her students. She had a way of making every child feel seen and valued, even when they were struggling. I remember her staying late after school to help kids who were falling behind, and she always said that education was the key to unlocking opportunities. She didn't just teach reading and math—she taught us how to think, how to care for others, and how to believe in ourselves. My dad worked at a local factory, assembling parts for machinery. His job wasn't glamorous, but he took pride in his work. He was the kind of person who showed up every day, no matter what, and he always made sure we had food on the table and a roof over our heads. He didn't talk much about his job, but I could tell he respected the people he worked with and took pride in doing his part. Both of them had different kinds of work, but they both showed me what it meant to be responsible, to work hard, and to care for others—even when life wasn't easy.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Jessica Bennett: My mom worked for the local school district, and she was part of a team of educators who were dedicated to making a difference in their students' lives. She taught middle school, and her classroom was always filled with books, art supplies, and a sense of curiosity. She made learning feel like an adventure, and I think that's why so many of her students went on to do great things. As for my dad, he worked for a manufacturing company that produced parts for industrial machines. His job was repetitive, but he took pride in the precision of his work. He used to say that even the smallest part could be the difference between a machine working or failing, and that taught me the value of attention to detail. Both of them worked in places that weren't always glamorous, but they gave their all, and that's something I'll always admire about them.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Jessica Bennett: A few years from now, I hope I'm still doing the work I love, but maybe with a little more stability and a little more freedom to dream bigger. I hope I'm still helping people in my community, but I also hope I'm building something more lasting—maybe a nonprofit of my own, or at least a program that supports young people in the way I was supported. I hope my sister is thriving in college, maybe even starting her own path in social work or something similar. I hope I'm still living in this neighborhood, but with a little more peace of mind, knowing that I've made a real difference in the lives of others. I also hope I'm taking better care of myself, not just physically but emotionally—finally learning to say no when I need to, to rest when I need to, and to celebrate the small victories instead of just pushing through. I don't know exactly what the future holds, but I hope it's filled with purpose, growth, and the kind of love and support that has carried me this far.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Jessica Bennett: What I value the most in my life is connection—real, meaningful connection with people. Whether it's my mom's quiet support, my dad's steady presence, my sister's quiet determination, or the clients I work with who trust me enough to share their struggles, those relationships are what give my life meaning. I also value resilience—the kind of resilience that comes from knowing you've faced challenges and still kept going. I think I've learned that life isn't about having everything perfect, but about showing up for the people you care about, even when things are hard. I value growth, too—both personal and collective. I want to be someone who keeps learning, keeps pushing forward, and keeps believing in the possibility of change, not just for myself, but for the community I'm part of. And finally, I value gratitude. Even in the hardest moments, I try to find something to be thankful for, because I know that without the struggles, I wouldn't have the strength or the perspective I have now.

It's not always easy to juggle everything, but I've come to accept that this is part of the journey—being there for others, even when it means working late or sacrificing personal time. I've also learned that financial stability isn't about having a lot, but about being responsible with what you have and knowing that every step you take, no matter how small, is part of a larger path toward growth and self-compassion.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been like looking at the different pieces of a puzzle I didn't realize I was holding. It reminded me of how much I've grown, not just in the big moments like choosing to leave my hometown or facing my mental health struggles, but also in the small, everyday choices—like journaling, cooking at home, or showing up for my sister. It's not perfect, but it's real, and it's mine. I'm proud of the journey I've taken, and I'm excited to see where it leads next.
